skill.name: dead-code-detector
skill.description: Identify unused code, imports, variables, and functions for safe removal.
skill.summary: Identify unused code, imports, variables, and functions for safe removal.
skill.author: CuriousLearner

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based skill containing only documentation and instructions for AI code analysis. The static findings are false positives caused by the analyzer misinterpreting JSON metadata fields and code examples as security patterns. The skill-report.json already contains a valid security audit (lines 37-52) that correctly assessed this skill as 'safe' with no executable code.

content.user_title: Clean Dead Code from Your Codebase
content.value_statement: Dead code bloats your codebase and increases maintenance burden. This skill analyzes your code to identify unused imports, variables, and functions that can be safely removed.
limitations: May flag test-only code as unused
Requires manual review for public API changes

use_cases.title: Clean Up Legacy Codebases
use_cases.description: Remove accumulated dead code in large, older projects to improve maintainability and reduce bundle size.

use_cases.title: Pre-Refactoring Analysis
use_cases.description: Before major refactoring, identify what code can be safely removed without affecting functionality.

use_cases.title: Optimize Build Artifacts
use_cases.description: Reduce bundle sizes and deployment artifacts by eliminating unused code and dependencies.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Dead Code Scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Scan my entire codebase for dead code including unused imports, variables, functions, and unreachable code. Focus on obvious issues that are safe to remove.

prompt_templates.title: Aggressive Cleanup Mode
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform an aggressive dead code analysis including commented code blocks, deprecated functions, and potentially unused exports. Flag everything but categorize by safety.

prompt_templates.title: Dependency Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze my package.json and codebase to find unused npm dependencies, dev dependencies used in production, and production dependencies only used in tests.

prompt_templates.title: Targeted File Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Focus on the src/components directory and identify all unused code. Pay special attention to React-specific patterns like unused props, state variables, and lifecycle methods.

output_examples.input: Scan my React project for dead code
output: - src/hooks/useData.js:15 const cache = new Map() (never referenced)

output_examples.input: Find unused npm packages in my project

best_practices: Always run tests after removing code to ensure nothing broke
Use version control to track removals for easy rollback
Be conservative with public API changes in libraries
anti_patterns: Removing code without understanding dynamic usage patterns
Aggressively removing all flagged code without review
Ignoring test-only code that appears unused

faq.question: How does this skill detect dead code?
faq.answer: It uses static analysis to find declarations without references, unreachable code paths, and unused imports based on coding patterns.

faq.question: Can it detect dynamically referenced code?
faq.answer: No, static analysis cannot detect code accessed via strings, reflection, or dynamic imports. These require manual review.

faq.question: Will it flag my test helper functions?
faq.answer: It might. Test-only code that is not properly excluded may appear unused. Use targeted analysis to focus on main code.

faq.question: Is it safe to remove everything flagged?
faq.answer: Only remove items marked Safe to Remove. Review Needs Review items manually as they might be public APIs.

faq.question: Which languages does it support?
faq.answer: Optimized for JavaScript and TypeScript. Can identify patterns in Python, Java, and other C-style languages.

faq.question: How is this different from ESLint?
faq.answer: ESLint focuses on code quality rules. This skill provides comprehensive dead code analysis including dependencies and cross-file references.
